title: What is McCarthyism? And how did it happen? - Ellen Schrecker

multiple-choice.question: What was the phenomenon known as McCarthyism?

options.label: A
options.text: A campaign to expose suspected communists in the United States, led by Senator Joseph McCarthy and characterized by widespread political repression and the harassment of individuals suspected of holding left-of-center views.

options.label: B
options.text: A campaign to expose suspected fascists in the United States.

options.label: C
options.text: A campaign to expose suspected socialists in the United States.

options.label: D
options.text: A campaign to expose suspected libertarians in the United States.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of the House Un-American Activities Committee?

options.label: A
options.text: To investigate crimes committed by American citizens suspected of being communists.

options.label: B
options.text: To investigate crimes committed by foreign nationals.

options.label: C
options.text: To investigate crimes committed by law enforcement officials.

options.label: D
options.text: To investigate crimes committed by corporate executives.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the campaign to eliminate domestic communism in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The threat of communism was eliminated, and the country became safer.

options.label: B
options.text: The campaign turned into the longest lasting and most widespread episode of political repression in American history, causing significant damage to democratic institutions and the lives of hundreds of individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: The campaign had no significant impact on the country.

options.label: D
options.text: The campaign led to the rise of a new communist government.

multiple-choice.question: Who was the FBI Director that used the resources of his agency to hunt down suspected communists?
What were the criteria used to screen federal employees during the campaign to eliminate domestic communism?

options.label: D
options.text: Their political views and associations with suspected communists, which often led to the harassment and blacklisting of individuals.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Korean War on Joseph McCarthy's power?

options.label: A
options.text: He became more powerful and influential.

options.label: B
options.text: He remained the same in power and influence.

options.label: C
options.text: His investigation of the army turned public opinion against him, diminishing his power and ultimately leading to his censure by the Senate.

options.label: D
options.text: He died before the war started.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Senate's censure of Joseph McCarthy?

options.label: C
options.text: He remained in office, but his influence and power were significantly diminished.

options.label: D
options.text: He died shortly after the censure.

multiple-choice.question: What was the damage to democratic institutions caused by McCarthyism?

options.label: A
options.text: It had no significant impact on the country.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the rise of a new communist government.

options.label: C
options.text: It drastically narrowed the American political spectrum, leading to the harassment and blacklisting of individuals suspected of holding left-of-center views.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the decline of civil liberties.

multiple-choice.question: Which institution failed to stop the witchhunt, condoning serious violations of constitutional rights in the name of national security?

options.label: A
options.text: The Supreme Court of the United States

multiple-choice.question: What was the likely outcome of new demagogues appearing in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities in the name of patriotism?

options.label: A
options.text: It would lead to the rise of a new communist government.

options.label: B
options.text: It would lead to the decline of civil liberties.

options.label: C
options.text: It could lead to the repetition of McCarthyism, causing further damage to democratic institutions and the lives of individuals.

options.label: D
options.text: It would have no significant impact on the country.

title: What happens during a heart attack? - Krishna Sudhir

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of oxygen to the heart muscle

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common symptom of a heart attack?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The injured muscle may not be able to pump blood as well, and its rhythm might be thrown off

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What can be done to prevent heart attacks?

options.label: B
options.text: Eat a healthy diet, low in sugar and saturated fats

options.label: B
options.text: A diet low in sugar and saturated fats, and high in fiber from vegetables, chicken and fish, whole grains and nuts

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A diet high in processed foods and low in fiber

multiple-choice.question: What is a common medication prescribed to prevent heart attacks?

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding exercise and eating a high-calorie diet

options.label: C
options.text: Eating a healthy diet and exercising a few times a week, and getting enough sleep and enjoying plenty of laughter

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding exercise and eating a high-calorie diet, and getting enough sleep and enjoying plenty of laughter

title: How small are we in the scale of the universe? - Alex Hofeldt

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The Hubble Telescope captured an image of over 400,000 galaxies in the first Deep Field image.

options.label: B
options.text: The Hubble Telescope captured an image of over 10,000 galaxies in the eXtreme Deep Field image.

options.label: C
options.text: The Hubble Telescope captured an image of over 3,000 galaxies in the first Deep Field image.

options.label: D
options.text: The Hubble Telescope captured an image of over 1,500 distinct galaxies in its first Deep Field image.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is heterogeneous, meaning that images taken at different spots in the sky look different.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe is homogeneous, meaning that images taken at different spots in the sky look similar.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is infinite, meaning that it has no boundaries.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is finite, meaning that it has a definite size.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The Deep Field images can be used to study the formation of galaxies in the present universe.

options.label: B
options.text: The Deep Field images can be used to study the formation of galaxies in the ancient universe.

options.label: C
options.text: The Deep Field images can be used to study the movement of stars in the present universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The Deep Field images can be used to study the movement of planets in the present universe.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The Deep Field images show galaxies that are only one billion years old.

options.label: B
options.text: The Deep Field images show galaxies that are only one ten-billionth the brightness that the human eye can perceive.

options.label: C
options.text: The Deep Field images show galaxies that are only one two-millionth the size of the night sky.

options.label: D
options.text: The Deep Field images show galaxies that existed over 13 billion years ago.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The average human measures about 1.7 meters.

options.label: B
options.text: The Earth's diameter is approximately 12,700 kilometers.

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun's diameter is approximately 1.4 million kilometers.

options.label: D
options.text: The Apollo 8 astronauts flew a distance of 380,000 kilometers to the moon.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is made up of only a few billion galaxies.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe is made up of hundreds of billions of galaxies.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is made up of an infinite number of galaxies.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is made up of no galaxies.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The Deep Field images can be used to study the formation of galaxies in the ancient universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The Deep Field images can be used to study the formation of galaxies in the present universe.

options.label: A
options.text: The Deep Field images show galaxies that are only one hundredth the size of the Milky Way.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The Deep Field images show galaxies that are only one billion years old.

options.label: D
options.text: The Hubble Telescope captured an image of over 1,500 distinct galaxies in the first Deep Field image.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is infinite, meaning that it has no boundaries.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is homogeneous, meaning that images taken at different spots in the sky look similar.

options.label: D

title: Would winning the lottery make you happier? - Raj Raghunathan

multiple-choice.question: According to a famous study of 22 lottery winners, what happened to their average reported levels of happiness months after winning the lottery?

options.label: A
options.text: Their levels of happiness decreased significantly

options.label: B
options.text: They reported levels of happiness that were the same as before winning

options.label: C
options.text: Their levels of happiness increased no more than that of a control group who hadn't won the lottery

options.label: D
options.text: Their levels of happiness increased dramatically

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon describes our tendency to adapt to new situations to maintain a stable emotional equilibrium?
What happens to our emotional well-being, how often and how intensely we feel things like joy, sorrow, anxiety, or anger, when it comes to wealth or status beyond a certain point?
According to the study with the lottery winners, what happened to people who had suffered an accident that left them paralyzed?

options.label: A
options.text: They reported levels of happiness that were significantly lower than before their accidents

options.label: B
options.text: They reported levels of happiness that were the same as before their accidents

options.label: C
options.text: They reported levels of happiness that were approaching their original baseline

options.label: D
options.text: They reported levels of happiness that were significantly higher than before their accidents

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to people who win the lottery and have difficulty managing large sums of money?

options.label: A
options.text: They tend to save more money

options.label: B
options.text: They tend to spend or lose their money quickly

options.label: C
options.text: They tend to invest their money wisely

options.label: D
options.text: They tend to donate their money to charity

multiple-choice.question: According to one study, what happened to participants who played a rigged game of monopoly where the experimenters made some players rich quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: They started sharing their snacks with the poorer players

options.label: B
options.text: They started patronizing the poorer players and hogging the snacks

options.label: C
options.text: They started donating their money to the poorer players

multiple-choice.question: What can happen when we spend money on experiences rather than things?

options.label: A
options.text: We tend to adapt to them faster

options.label: B
options.text: We tend to be less happy

options.label: C
options.text: We tend to be more anxious

multiple-choice.question: According to one study, what happened when participants were given some money and were either asked to spend it on themselves or on someone else?

options.label: A
options.text: The happiness levels of those who had spent the money on themselves were significantly greater

options.label: B
options.text: The happiness levels of those who had spent the money on others were significantly greater

options.label: C
options.text: The happiness levels of those who had spent the money on themselves and others were the same

options.label: D
options.text: The happiness levels of those who had spent the money on themselves and others were significantly lower

multiple-choice.question: According to another study, what happened to people who donated in over 90% of the countries examined?

options.label: A
options.text: They tended to be less happy

options.label: B
options.text: They tended to be the same as those who didn't donate

options.label: D
options.text: They tended to be more anxious

multiple-choice.question: What might happen if a million dollars falls into your lap tomorrow?

options.label: B
options.text: You would automatically be less happy

options.label: C
options.text: You would have to decide what to do with it

options.label: D
options.text: You would have to donate it to charity

title: Everything you need to know to read Homer's "Odyssey" - Jill Dash

multiple-choice.question: According to tradition, who is the author of the "Odyssey"?
In what century BCE was the Greek alphabet first introduced?

options.label: A
options.text: To describe the relationship between Odysseus and his family

options.label: B
options.text: To explain the role of the gods in the story

options.label: C
options.text: To show the importance of hospitality in Ancient Greek culture

options.label: D
options.text: To recount the events of the Trojan War

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of combining existing stories, jokes, myths, and songs into a single narrative?

options.label: B
options.text: The role of the gods in human life

options.label: C
options.text: Do not incur the wrath of the gods

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the code of hospitality practiced by the Ancient Greeks?
In what context is xenia practiced in the "Odyssey"?

options.label: B
options.text: Between Odysseus and his hosts on his travels

options.label: D
options.text: Between the characters and the author

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the island where Odysseus is trapped at the beginning of the narrative?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he has angered the sea god Poseidon

options.label: B
options.text: Because he has forgotten his way

options.label: C
options.text: Because he has lost his memory

options.label: D
options.text: Because he has been betrayed by his friends

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of Odysseus's wife in the "Odyssey"?
What is the name of the famous epic that tells the story of the Trojan War?
How long was Odysseus away from his native Ithaca and his family?
